Box 16100, FI-00076, Finland ⁎ Corresponding author at: Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science and Technology, State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering (Tianjin University), School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Tianjin Key Laboratory of Applied Catalysis Science and Technology, State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering (Tianjin University), School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Developing high-performance catalyst is of paramount importance for NO direct decomposition. Here, composite catalysts BaMnO3-CeO2 were designed and prepared by the one-pot method, which show high catalytic activity, oxygen resistance and durability. The NO conversion to N2 of 85.9% at 800 °C is achieved over 5%BaMnO3-CeO2. It exhibits 66.5% activity in the presence of 10 vol% O2 and runs stable for more than 200 h in 5 vol% O2 at 800 °C. The high performance is originated from the strong interaction between BaMnO3 and CeO2 components, where CeO2 can effectively inhibit the sintering of BaMnO3 particles, enhance the redox activity, mobility of lattice oxygen and NO sorption. The proposed catalytic mechanism based on diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy and kinetic study reveals that the formation of N2O* intermediate species is the rate determining step. BaMnO3-CeO2 composite can be a promising catalyst candidate for NO direct decomposition. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NO direct decomposition One-pot Perovskite BaMnO3 CeO2 1 Introduction The nitrogen oxides (NOx, including mainly NO and NO2) in the flue gas of the new-type dry cement production process, can be as high as 800 °C. They jeopardize human health and natural environment by acid rain, photochemical smog, and ozone layer depletion. Various technologies have been explored for NOx abatement including selective catalytic reduction (SCR), selective non-catalytic reduction and NOx storage and reduction [1]. Among them, NO direct decomposition (2NO → N2 + O2), which is eco-friendly and requires no reductant, is deemed as the most desirable NOx abatement technology. Thermodynamically, NO can decompose into N2 and O2 easily (ΔG = − 76.9 kJ mol−1@800 °C, 100 kPa), but kinetically, it is a sluggish reaction due to the high activation energy (~ 335 kJ mol−1) [2]. Therefore, the key to the NO direct decomposition technology is to develop high-performance catalysts. Since Jellinek [3] first studied the noble metals for NO decomposition in 1906, many catalysts have been developed such as simple metal oxides, rare-earth metal oxides (REOs), perovskite-type (like) metal oxides (ABO3, A2BO4), zeolites and other catalysts [2]. Among those catalysts, the ABO3-type oxides have captured wide attention due to their attractive NO decomposition activity, high sulphur-resistance at elevated temperatures, high thermal stability, and composition versatility [4]. The La-based (LaMO3, M = Ni, Co, Mn, Fe, Cr) [5] and Ba-based [6] perovskites are typical examples. Their activities can be significantly promoted by substitution at A- and/or B-sites. The N2 yield in the presence of La0.8Sr0.2CoO3 and La0.4Sr0.6Mn0.8Ni0.2O3 is 55% and 66% at 800 °C and 4 g s cm−3, respectively [7]. La0.7Ba0.3Mn0.8In0.2O3 displays 64% N2 yield at 800 °C and 3 g s cm−3 [8]. The N2 yield over Ba0.8La0.2Mn0.8Mg0.2O3 catalyst increases to 74% at 850 °C and 3 g s cm−3 [6]. However, their application is limited by poor oxygen resistance and fast activity decline at shorter contact time. The N2 yield over La0.7Ba0.3Mn0.8In0.2O3 decreases to 12% in the presence of 10 vol% O2 [8], and Ba0.8La0.2Mn0.8Mg0.2O3 to 40% in 5 vol% O2 [6]. In addition, the activity declines quickly with decreased contact time due to low specific surface area (SSA) [8]. Therefore, efforts are needed to develop high surface area ABO3-type oxides with robust resistance to oxygen. CeO2, characterized by high oxygen storage capacity and feasible transformation between Ce4+ and Ce3+, has been widely applied in heterogeneous catalysis [9,10], including NO direct decomposition. Hong et al. [11] reported that the Ba loaded Ce-Mn oxides exhibit excellent activity towards NO decomposition and the oxide ion vacancy produced by incorporation of Mn2+ into CeO2 plays an important role. Reddy et al. [12] prepared transition-metal doped CeO2 by the co-precipitation method and found that the Ce-Ni catalyst exhibits 100% N2 selectivity at 400 °C and gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2100 h−1. In addition, the Ce dopant can efficiently enhance the oxygen tolerance of La0.7Ce0.3SrNiO4 [13] and La0.6Ce0.4CoO3 [14]. However, very limited work focuses on using CeO2 as a support for ABO3 for NO direct decomposition [15,16], although it has been widely used in other heterogeneous catalysis [10]. Herein, the BaMnO3-CeO2 catalysts were designed considering the impressive catalytic performance [6] and sintering-resistance of BaMnO3 single component. The catalysts were prepared by the one-pot method, which is a very promising method to prepare composite materials as has been widely employed [17–19]. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on one-pot derived BaMnO3-CeO2 as NO direct decomposition catalyst. BaMnO3-CeO2 display high catalytic activity, oxygen resistance and durability. 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 exhibits 66.5% activity in the presence of 10 vol% O2 at 800 °C and runs stable for more than 200 h in 5 vol% O2 at 800 °C. The interaction between the two components was revealed by various characterization and the catalytic mechanism was discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts xBaMnO3-CeO2 (x = 0–100%) were synthesized by the citric acid-nitrate one-pot method, where x is the weight percent of BaMnO3. Briefly, appropriate amounts of Ba(NO3)2, Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in de-ionized water, followed by addition of ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) and citric acid. The molar ratio of total metal ions:EDTA:citric acid was 1:1:2. The pH of the solution was adjusted to ~ 8 by ammonia hydroxide. The solution was heated in a water bath at 80 °C to form a sol, then a gel, and finally combusted when heated at ~ 400 °C on a hot plate. The combusted powders were calcined at 700 °C for 6 h to obtain the catalyst. The pure BaMnO3 and CeO2 were prepared by similar procedure. 2.2 Catalytic performance test The catalyst powders were pressed, crushed and sieved into particles of 40–60 mesh. NO direct decomposition was performed with fixed-bed quartz glass tube reactor of 10 mm internal diameter (3.8 mm for 0.5 g catalyst bed height) in 2 vol% NO/He (20 mL min−1) with the contact time of 1.5 g s cm−3. N2 concentration in the effluent gas was analyzed by the online gas chromatography system (GC, Agilent 6890N) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and molecular sieve 5A column. Steady-state catalytic activity was measured at each temperature maintaining 0.5 h repeating more than three times until stable values were obtained, when the reaction temperature raised from 500 to 850 °C with an interval of 50 °C. The catalytic activity is evaluated by the NO conversion to N2 (Eq. (1)) based on the plug flow reactor model [20]. (1) N O c o n v e r s i o n t o N 2 = 2 N 2 o u t N O i n × 100 % Where [NO]in and [N2]out represent the reactor inlet and outlet concentration of NO and N2, respectively. N2O was hardly produced during the decomposition of NO, whereas NO2 was the possible product of NO and O2 in the cool zone between the reactor and the GC [8,21]. The oxygen resistance of the catalysts was evaluated by introducing 1, 3, 5 and 10 vol% O2, while keeping the total flow rate constant by adjusting He. The kinetic study was performed with 1–4 vol% NO and 1–10 vol% O2 at 600–850 °C. In addition, the rate of N2 formation was determined by Eq. (2), which is also the reaction rate at the reactor outlet. under different reaction conditions to ensure the NO conversion to N2 is < 30% by varying the catalyst weight from 0.025 to 0.1 g. (2) r N 2 = F ⋅ c ⋅ α W where F, c, α and W are the feed flow (mol min−1), NO inlet concentration (vol%), NO conversion to N2 (%) and weight of the catalyst (g), respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/Max-2500) was performed with monochromatic Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 20–80° at a scan rate of 2° min−1. The SSA was measured on Quantachrome Autosorb-1 with nitrogen sorption at − 196 °C and the samples were degassed at 250 °C for 4 h under vacuum before test. The microstructure was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Apreo S LoVac), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-F200) and scanning transmission electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (STEM-EDX mapping). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab-250Xi) was conducted on a SPECS system with Al Kα as X-ray source under a vacuum pressure of 5 × 10−8 Pa. The binding energy was calibrated with adventitious carbon 1 s at 284.8 eV. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR, Xianquan TP-5076) was conducted to examine the reducibility. The samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature (RT) under pure N2 before running TPR test in 5 vol% H2/N2 (30 mL min−1). Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD, Xianquan TP-5076) and NO-TPD (Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS10) were carried out to analyze the O2 and NO desorption property, respectively. For O2-TPD, the catalysts were pretreated at 500 °C for 30 min and cooled to RT under pure O2 (30 mL min−1), followed by testing in pure He from RT to 1000 °C. For NO-TPD, the samples were pretreated at 700 °C for 1 h and cooled to 80 °C under pure Ar, then under 2 vol% NO/He for 1 h until saturation adsorption was achieved. Afterwards, NO-TPD was tested in pure Ar from 80 to 700 °C. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS, Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS50) was performed to monitor the reaction intermediates. The sample was pretreated at 600 °C for 1 h under pure He atmosphere and then cooled down to room temperature. The background spectra at certain temperatures were collected during cooling. Afterwards, 2 vol% NO/He without/with 5 vol% O2 was introduced with temperature increasing from RT to 600 °C. The spectra were collected at 25, 200, 400, 550 and 600 °C, respectively, in the range of 800–2500 cm−1 with a resolution of 0.09 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NO decomposition performance The NO conversion to N2 of xBaMnO3-CeO2 along with pure BaMnO3 and CeO2 is shown in Fig. 1 and the conversion to O2 is supplied in Fig. S1. It is obvious that the apparent NO conversion to O2 is always lower than NO conversion to N2. It is related to NO2 formation (oxidation of unreacted NO by O2 generated through NO decomposition) in the cool zone after the reaction, which is widely reported [6,8,21]. The pure CeO2 is almost inactive and pure BaMnO3 exhibits activity of only 12.2% at 800 °C. Attractively, the activity increases by four times (61.3%) when 25% CeO2 was introduced. The catalytic activity increases with CeO2 content (i.e., decreased BaMnO3 content); 88.0%, 88.6% and 85.9% at 800 °C and 1.5 g s cm−3 for samples with x = 20%, 10% and 5%, respectively. Furthermore, the sample with x = 5% shows activity of 69.2% and 81.2% at 700 and 750 °C, respectively. Such activity is outstanding compared with the reported, e.g., 75.6% for 5%BaCoO3-CeO2 (800 °C, 1.5 g s cm−3) [15], 66% for La0.4Sr0.6Mn0.8Ni0.2O3 (800 °C, 4 g s cm−3) [7], 64% for La0.7Ba0.3Mn0.8In0.2O3 (800 °C, 3 g s cm−3) [8] and 74% for Ba0.8La0.2Mn0.8Mg0.2O3 (850 °C, 3 g s cm−3) [6]. The activity starts to decline for 3%BaMnO3-CeO2, which is probably due to very small number of active sites in this catalyst. In addition, the present BaMnO3-CeO2 shows high sintering resistance, which is believed to be related with the refractory nature of BaMnO3. In the following study, 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 was used. The O2-resistance is always a concern for NO decomposition catalyst [2]. The O2-tolerance of 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 was examined by introducing 1–10 vol% O2. As shown in Fig. 2a, the activity decreases with O2 content, but at a very gentle degree especially at high temperatures due to easier desorption of O2 [6]. The activity decreases from 85.9% to 83.0%, 76.5%, 70.7% and 66.5% at 800 °C under 1, 3, 5 and 10 vol% O2, respectively. Such O2-resistance is superior to most reported catalysts. The activity over 5%BaCoO3-CeO2 [15] and La0.7Ba0.3Mn0.8In0.2O3 [8] at 800 °C decrease from 75.6% and 64% to 54.3% and 12% in the presence of 10 vol% O2, respectively. The N2 yield decreases from 74% and 75% to 40% and 52% in the presence of 5 vol% O2 over Ba0.8La0.2Mn0.8Mg0.2O3 [6] and (Y0.78Pr0.15Eu0.07)2O3±σ [22] at 850 °C, respectively. Notably, these catalysts were all tested at higher contact time (3 g s cm−3) except 5%BaCoO3-CeO2 (1.5 g s cm−3). Furthermore, 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 shows stable durability in the 5 vol% O2-containing atmosphere at 800 °C at least over 200 h with only ~10% decrease (Fig. 2b), which is impressive compared with Ba3Y3.6Cu0.4O9 (N2 yield decreases from 75% to 60% under 1% O2 at 700 °C after 21 h) [23] and K/Co-Mn-Al (NO conversion decreases from 65% to 50% at 650 °C without O2 after 80 h) [24]. As aforementioned, the activity of ABO3 declines quickly with the decrease of contact time, which is a great challenge for its practical application. Here, the activity of 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 at different contact time was tested and the results are shown in Fig. 3. The activity decreases gradually from 86.2% at 2 g s cm−3 to 85.9%, 77.9% and 69.6% at 1.5, 1 and 0.5 g s cm−3, respectively, at 800 °C. However, the activity plunges to only 30.2% when contact time further decreases to 0.075 g s cm−3. Compared with other catalysts, 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 exhibits better performance under shorter contact time. For example, the N2 yield in the presence of La0.7Ba0.3Mn0.8In0.2O3 decreases from 64% at 3 g s cm−3 to 35% at 1.5 g s cm−3, 800 °C [8]. The N2 yield declines from ~ 73 to ~ 28% when the contact time decreases from 3 to 0.375 g s cm−3 over (Gd0.70Y0.26Ba0.04)2O2.96 at 800 °C [25]. Such performance is probably associated with higher SSA, as discussed later. 3.2 Phase composition and microstructure To explore the reasons for the high-performance of xBaMnO3-CeO2, comprehensive characterization was performed. First, the phase composition of the catalysts was examined by XRD ( Fig. 4a). BaMnO3 is the main phase with minor Ba3Mn2O8, in the 700 °C-calcined BaMnO3 sample. The Ba3Mn2O8 impurity was also found by others [6,26]. The influence of Ba3Mn2O8 impurity on the activity is negligible, as discussed in the Supporting information (Fig. S2). With the increment of CeO2, the peak intensity of BaMnO3 decreases whereas that of CeO2 gradually increases. The characteristic peaks of BaMnO3 disappear when the content of BaMnO3 decreases to less than 10%, probably due to its highly dispersed nature. In addition, no evident shift of the diffraction peaks is observed (Fig. 4b), which suggests that the inter-diffusion of the two components is very limited if existed. The diffraction peaks of BaMnO3 and CeO2 in xBaMnO3-CeO2 are broader compared with their single components, which indicates that the two components suppress the sintering of each other in the one-pot prepared catalysts. Such conclusion can be further supported by the BET results. The SSA is 48.5, 52.4, 48.3, 33.0, 23.9 and 14.9 m2 g−1 for 3%, 5%, 10%, 20%, 50% and 75%BaMnO3-CeO2, respectively, which is impressive compared with that for the pure components (7.8 and 24.0 m2 g−1 for BaMnO3 and CeO2, respectively). To illustrate the influence of SSA on activity, the relationship between conversion and SSA is provided in Fig. 5. Generally, the activity increases with SSA. However, the activity varies very slightly when SSA > 30 m2 g−1, especially, the 3% sample with high SSA even shows declined activity. It infers that beside the geometric factor, the electronic factor also plays an important role for the present catalysts. The improved sintering resistance in the one-pot prepared xBaMnO3-CeO2 can also be reflected by the SEM results (Fig. S3). The fine CeO2 particles are coated on the larger BaMnO3 particles, which can prevent the agglomeration of BaMnO3 particles and thus improve SSA and catalytic activity. Accordingly, the O2 molecules are expected to be preferentially adsorbed on the CeO2 surface, which can alleviate the competitive adsorption on the active sites of BaMnO3, leading to improved O2-resistance of 5%BaMnO3-CeO2. However, superabundant CeO2 may cover the active sites on the surface of BaMnO3, which should be responsible for the slight declined activity of 3%BaMnO3-CeO2. Since the catalysts were prepared by the citric acid-nitrate one-pot method, homogeneous distribution and more interfaces are expected. To prove that, the TEM images were collected and the results are shown in Fig. 6. The obvious lattice fringes of 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 with lattice space of 3.06, 3.21, 3.23 and 2.78 Å match well with those of the (111) and (200) planes of CeO2 whilst those with 2.82, 1.70 and 1.65 Å are assigned to the (110), (202) and (300) planes of BaMnO3, respectively. Both components contact with each other closely, which is beneficial for strong interaction. In addition, Ba, Ce and Mn elements are uniformly distributed in 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 based on the STEM-EDX mapping. 3.3 XPS and chemisorption To reveal the interaction between the two components in xBaMnO3-CeO2, XPS was run and the results are shown in Fig. 7. For the Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 7a), both Ce3+ (v′ and u′) and Ce4+ (other peaks) exist [27]. The peak positions remain unchanged for all the samples. For the Mn 2p spectra (Fig. 7b), it is highly difficult to distinguish the oxidation states of manganese species since there is a significant overlap of peaks related to the various oxidation states. However, the absence of a satellite peak at + 5 eV from the Mn 2p3/2 peak suggests that no Mn2+ is present in our catalysts [28]. The peaks at ~ 641.7 and ~ 653.2 eV belong to Mn3+ whilst those at ~ 642.6 and ~ 654.1 eV to Mn4+ [26,27,29]. The Mn species mainly exist as Mn4+. The presence of Mn3+ can introduce oxide ion vacancy, which is recognized as the active site for perovskite-type catalysts [7]. For the Ba 3d spectra (Fig. 7c), the peaks at ~ 779.2 and ~ 794.5 eV are assigned to Ba2+ in the perovskite structure whilst those at ~ 780.4 and ~ 795.7 eV to Ba2+ in BaCO3 [27]. The binding energy of Ba 3d spectra shifts to higher value and relative peaks area of Ba2+ in BaCO3 increases as the BaMnO3 content decreases to less than 20%, which indicates the transformation of Ba2+ in perovskite to BaCO3 due to its highly dispersed nature and interaction with CO2 in the atmosphere. The formation of CO3 2- can be further consolidated by the O 1s (Fig. 7d) and C 1s (Fig. S4) spectra. The O 1s spectra can be divided into lattice oxygen (OI, 529.0–529.2 eV), surficial adsorbed oxygen and carbonate species (OII, 530.9–531.3 eV) and adsorbed molecular water (OIII, 533.1–534.5 eV) [27]. With the introduction of CeO2, the content of OII gradually increases probably due to increased BaCO3 species. The C 1s spectra can be assigned to C-C (284.8 eV), C-O (285.7–286.2 eV) and carbonate species (288.6–288.9 eV), respectively [27]. The BaCO3 species at the surface is around 1.5, 2.6, 4.7, 2.4, 3.9 and 4.9 wt% for 5%, 10%, 20%, 50%, 75% BaMnO3-CeO2 and pure BaMnO3 catalysts, respectively. BaCO3 has been reported to be beneficial for NO direct decomposition as NOx storage component [30]. To further unearth the underlying reasons for the high performance of xBaMnO3-CeO2, chemisorption was run. The H2-TPR profile ( Fig. 8a) of BaMnO3 sample shows three main peaks at ~ 440, ~ 700 and ~ 875 °C, which correspond to the reduction of Mn4+ and Mn3+ to Mn2+ species in the bulk, and decomposition of carbonate, respectively [31,32]. The shoulder peaks at ~ 410 and ~ 480 °C are due to the reduction of Mn4+ and Mn3+ species at the surface [31]. Pure CeO2 exhibits two peaks at ~ 510 and ~ 780 °C due to the reduction of Ce4+ species at the surface and in the bulk, respectively [15,16]. The reduction temperatures for all species decrease in xBaMnO3-CeO2 with decreased BaMnO3 content. Compared with pure BaMnO3, the bulk reduction temperature of Mn4+ and Mn3+ species decreases by ~ 40 and ~ 190 °C for 10%BaMnO3-CeO2. It suggests that the interaction between the two components significantly enhance the redox activity of Mn and Ce species in xBaMnO3-CeO2, which is beneficial for NO decomposition. For O2-TPD profile (Fig. 8b) of BaMnO3 sample, three desorption peaks are corresponding to chemically adsorbed oxygen species (α oxygen, O2 -, < 200 °C), oxygen at the surface oxide ion vacancy (β oxygen, O-, 400–600 °C) and lattice oxygen (γ oxygen, O2-, > 700 °C), respectively [15,16,23]. The desorption peaks of α and β oxygen shift to higher temperatures whereas γ oxygen to lower temperature with decreased BaMnO3. It suggests that the interaction between two components significantly improves the mobility of lattice oxygen and accelerates the desorption of oxygen species, which enhances the catalytic activity and oxygen resistance. The oxide ion vacancy is generally recognized as the active site for NO sorption [7]. For NO-TPD profiles (Fig. 8c), there are three NO desorption peaks at 150, 250 and 400 °C for BaMnO3 and one peak for CeO2 at 450 °C, which are assigned to decomposition of nitrite, decomposition of unstable bridging bidentate nitrate species, and decomposition of chelating bidentate and monodentate nitrate, respectively [33]. The NO2 desorption peaks (100–400 °C) are probably due to the decomposition of nitrite and nitrate species. The adsorbed NO and NO2 is inset in Fig. 8c. The total adsorption content of NO and NO2 for samples with x = 5%, 10% and 20% is 353.1, 537.9 and 297.9 μmol g−1, respectively, all surpassing that of BaMnO3 (94.7 μmol g−1) and CeO2 (107.8 μmol g−1). Accordingly, the interaction between CeO2 and BaMnO3 substantially enhances the NO adsorption capability, leading to increased catalytic activity. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism Considering the impressive performance of the one-pot prepared 5%BaMnO3-CeO2, the catalytic mechanism was explored by DRIFTS and kinetic study. Fig. 9 shows the DRIFTS profiles under 2 vol% NO/He without/with the presence of 5 vol% O2. The detailed bands and their assignment [33–43] are provided in Table 1. For the DRIFTS profile in 2%NO/He (Fig. 9a), the absorption band of nitrous oxide (N2O) at 2225 cm−1 is weak at 25 °C but becomes stronger when temperature elevates to 200 °C and then almost disappears above 550 °C. It indicates that some NO sorption species transforms to N2O and subsequently decomposes fast at higher temperature [8]. The absorption band at 1900 cm−1 due to mononitrosyl (NO) species on Mn3+ is strong at 200 °C and almost disappears above 550 °C; meanwhile, the vibration of monodentate NO2 - on Mnn+ is observed at 1084 cm−1 above 200 °C, which indicates the transformation of NO to NO2 - on Mn3+. It infers that the Mn species is probably the active sites for NO direct decomposition and NO2 - species is the intermediate. The strong absorption bands at 1610–1240 cm−1 are originated from nitrate and nitrite species of different structures [44], which become stronger when temperature increases to 200 °C. Those species decompose at 400 °C as evidenced by the decreased band strength, but they are still the main adsorbed species at the surface. They almost disappear when the temperature increases to > 550 °C. It suggests that those nitrate and nitrite species are possible intermediates during NO decomposition [45]. In addition, the band at 808 cm−1 for the chelating bidentate NO2 - species absorbed on CeO2 indicates that CeO2 may be the absorption sites for NO direct decomposition. To explore the effect of O2 on the formation of intermediate species during catalysis, the DRIFTS profiles in 5 vol% O2-containing atmosphere were also collected and are shown in Fig. 9b. Although similar with the case without O2, noticeable differences still exist. The new band at 1632 cm−1 due to NO2 formed by reaction of NO and O2 appears and it becomes weaker with temperature, indicating that NO2 is weakly absorbed on the surface, which is consistent with the NO-TPD results. In addition, the absorption bands of monodentate NO3 - at 1489, 1280 and 1005 cm−1 become stronger with temperature, and remain even at 550 and 600 °C. It infers that O2 promotes the formation of stable nitrate species on the catalyst surface [46], which hampers the catalytic activity [8,38]. Hence, the active intermediate species are more likely to be nitrite species rather than nitrate species. Based on the DRIFTS results, a possible catalytic mechanism is proposed ( Table 2): the reaction is initiated by the adsorption of NO onto the active sites (*) to form mononitrosyl (NO*, step 1), which interacts with lattice oxygen to form nitrite species and release oxide ion vacancy ([ ]-) (step 2). As the temperature increases to 200 °C, both steps (1) and (2) are significantly accelerated. Step 2 is believed to proceed fast considering the high mobility of lattice oxygen (Fig. 7b). Then, the nitrite species react with NO* and [ ]- to produce N2O*, lattice oxygen and O* (step 3) [45]. The N2O* species further decompose into N2 and another adsorbed surface oxygen (step 4); this step is fast. Finally, the adjacent adsorbed oxygen species combine to generate O2 molecule and release the active sites (step 5), which is ready for next cycle. According to this mechanism, the lattice oxygen not only participate in the catalytic reaction but also is released, which indicates that the mobility of lattice oxygen plays a vital role in NO direct decomposition, which is consistent with the O2-TPD results. Assuming that one elementary reaction is the rate determining step (RDS) and the others are in the rapid equilibrium, the rate equations can be derived (Eqs. (3)–(7) in Table 2). Since the decomposition of N2O is the fast step, partial pressure of N2 at surface of catalysts is negligible [8]. Therefore, the simplified rate equations (Eqs. (8)–(12)) and theoretical reaction orders of NO, O2 (nNO, nO 2) can be obtained (Table 2). To determine the RDS for the present catalysts, kinetic experiments were performed and the resultant reaction orders of NO and O2 are [0.71, 1.06] and [− 0.52, − 0.39], respectively ( Fig. 10). However, we preferentially use the reaction orders at 600 and 650 °C, which is similar to those studied in the DRIFTS experiments. It should be noted that the influence of external diffusion can be neglected under the present experimental conditions (Fig. S5) so that the kinetic study can be performed. The decomposition of N2O* species (step 4) is a fast step [8] and the formation of nitrite is very easy according to DRIFTS. Taking all those into account, step 3 is more likely the RDS for 5%BaMnO3-CeO2. Such mechanism is reasonable considering the difficulty of desorption of oxygen from the oxide ion vacancy based on the O2-TPD results. Improving the desorption of oxygen species from the oxide ion vacancy along with the mobility of lattice oxygen is important to further enhance the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, composite catalysts BaMnO3-CeO2 prepared by the one-pot method show extraordinary catalytic activity even under shorter contact time, outstanding oxygen resistance and decent durability. NO conversion to N2 of 85.9%, 88.6% and 88.0% at 800 °C is obtained over 5%, 10% and 20%BaMnO3-CeO2, respectively. 5%BaMnO3-CeO2 exhibits 83.0%, 76.5%, 70.7%, and 66.5% activity in the presence of 1, 3, 5 and 10 vol% O2 at 800 °C, respectively. Additionally, it runs stable for more than 200 h in 5 vol% O2 at 800 °C with only ~ 10% decrease. Such attracting performance can be attributed to the strong interaction between BaMnO3 and CeO2 components, where CeO2 can improve the sintering-resistance, redox activity, mobility of lattice oxygen, and NO sorption. The proposed catalytic mechanism based on DRIFTS and the kinetic study reveals that the formation of N2O* intermediate species is the RDS; both the content of oxide ion vacancy and the mobility of lattice oxygen are important during catalysis. The outstanding performance and scalable fabrication enable one-pot derived 5–20%BaMnO3-CeO2 to be promising catalysts for NO direct decomposition. This work sheds light on the design and preparation of high performance catalysts, not only for NO direct decomposition, but also for other heterogeneous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Developing high-performance catalyst is of paramount importance for NO direct decomposition. Here, composite catalysts BaMnO3-CeO2 were designed and prepared by the one-pot method, which show high catalytic activity, oxygen resistance and durability. The NO conversion to N2 of 85.9% at 800 °C is achieved over 5%BaMnO3-CeO2. It exhibits 66.5% activity in the presence of 10 vol% O2 and runs stable for more than 200 h in 5 vol% O2 at 800 °C. The high performance is originated from the strong interaction between BaMnO3 and CeO2 components, where CeO2 can effectively inhibit the sintering of BaMnO3 particles, enhance the redox activity, mobility of lattice oxygen and NO sorption. The proposed catalytic mechanism based on diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy and kinetic study reveals that the formation of N2O* intermediate species is the rate determining step. BaMnO3-CeO2 composite can be a promising catalyst candidate for NO direct decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient NO direct decomposition over BaMnO3-CeO2 composite catalysts
